hammer.api

Class TypeToken<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • hammer.api.TypeToken<T>

  • public abstract class TypeToken<T>
extends Object
    A TypeToken is used to combat type erasure and allow introspection of parameterized types. As a declared abstract class, an instance of TypeToken by definition, must be a subclass. Subclasses have access to complete type information of declared superclasses at runtime so the type of T of an instantiated TypeToken is always reifiable. Typical usage of this class involves instantiating an anonymous subclass, i.e. (new TypeToken<Set<Integer>>() {})

    A TypeToken can be instantiated for any type bound to T with the following exceptions:

    • Type variables are not allowed in any form (i.e. new TypeToken<Set<T>>() {} is not allowed)
    • Inner classes and local classes are not allowed to be used as TypeTokens

    • Constructor Summary

      Modifier Constructor and Description
      protected TypeToken()
      Constructs a new TypeToken, extracting the type information from the superclass for easy introspection.
